definitions.conditionExpression: For patients who have 1 of the following less well-validated risk factors (age 65 to 74 y, female gender, or CAD)
patient needs stroke prevention AND patient refuses OAC AND patient cannot tolerate aspirin-clopidogrel combination therapy
patient < 65 years and lone AF (including females)
age < 65 and lone AF

non-valvular AF AND (previous stroke OR TIA OR systemic embolism OR LVEF (left ventricular ejection fraction) < 40% AND symptomatic heart failure AND (age >= 75 OR (age >=65 AND (diabetes OR coronary artery disease OR hypertension)))
recurrent (paroxymal or persistent) AF AND after cardioversion AND (high risk for drug-induced adverse effects OR high risk with infrequent recurrences of AF)
for patients with persistent or permanent AF
in the absence of preexcitation
in patients with AF and HF who do not have an accessory pathway
In patients who experience symptoms related to AF during activity
for patients with HF, LV dysfunction, or for sedentary individuals
when pharmacological therapy is insufficient or associated with side effects
in patients with AF when other measures are unsuccessful or contraindicated
When electrical cardioversion is not necessary in patients with AF and an accessory pathway
When the ventricular rate cannot be adequately controlled both at rest and during exercise in patients with AF using a beta blocker
for hemodynamically stable patients with AF involving conduction over an accessory pathway
When the rate cannot be controlled with pharmacological agents or tachycardia-mediated cardiomyopathy is suspected AND in patients with AF
for all patients with AF, except those with lone AF or contraindications
For patients without mechanical heart valves at high risk of stroke

for patients with more than 1 moderate risk factor. Such factors include age 75 y or greater, hypertension, HF, impaired LV systolic function (ejection fraction 35% or less or fractional shortening less than 25%), and diabetes mellitus
in low-risk patients or in those with contraindications to oral anticoagulation
For patients with AF who have mechanical heart valves
for patients with atrial flutter as for those with AF

in patients with nonvalvular AF who have just 1 of the following validated risk factors (age greater than or equal to 75 y (especially in female patients), hypertension, HF, impaired LV function, or diabetes mellitus)
For patients with nonvalvular AF who have 1 or more of the following less well-validated risk factors (age 65 to 74 y, female gender, or CAD)
In patients with AF who do not have mechanical prosthetic heart valves

In patients 75 y of age and older at increased risk of bleeding but without frank contraindications to oral anticoagulant therapy, and in other patients with moderate risk factors for thromboembolism who are unable to safely tolerate anticoagulation at the standard intensity of INR 2.0 to 3.0
